THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1907.

div.head: PORT SAID.
div.p: Egypt, the land of the Pharoahs, where things, writes a tourist, new and old ever meet the eye in striking juxtaposition, continues winter after winter to draw to herself the leisured classes of all nations, and Port Said, the door through which the greater number of visitors gain entrance to that land, is now receiving her daily shiploads of human cargo of a superior order. Frills and frocks from London, Paris and New-York arrive almost hourly and and may be noon passing along the streets and in and out of the shops, while their radiant owners make their first acquaintance with oriental sights and sounds, or renew it with evident satisfaction.

Port Said, however, in the minds of most travellers, is a place to be hurried through. An hour or two can, perhaps, be pleasantly enough occupied in lounging about and stretching one's legs after a week or more at sea, but the possibility of being compelled to stay there for some days, as not unfrequently happens, is regarded as an eventuality to be avoided at all costs. Great improvements have, nevertheless, of late years been made at the Port, and the adverse epithets that were so generally hurled at it in former days are now no longer so applicable. The town has developed in every direction. The main streets are well laid out and, for the most part; are excellently kept. Large buildings have grown up to accommodate the business "houses which trade there, and tho wave of prosperity which he spread over Egypt generally has left manifes effects on the town.

As regards the style of the buildings, not much can be said in its favour. There are some few fine blocks of offices of quite pleasing exterior and some especially grandiose and imposing edifices, such as the offices of the Suez Canal Company, but the construction of the bulk of the houses is, for the most part, in hideous style and has no claim to architectural beauty whatever. The jetty, a mile and a half long, with the bold and somewhat theatrical statue of De Lesseps, provides a pleasant promenade for one's morning constitutional, where a refreshing sea-blow can always be had. A short drive takes one to the waterworks to the East of the town, situated at the entrance to the Suez Canal, and here one can enjoy a quiet walk along the Canal bank and watch the shipping which is never lacking.

Few places can surely be more cosmopolitan than Port Said, not so much in regard to the visitors as in the composition of its residents. Egyptians, Turks, Greeks, Italians, French, English, Russians, Datoh, all are there in considerable numbers, . and the coinage of almost any country is current. Unfortunately, too, the least desirable habits and customs of these various countries have impressed them. selves upon the life of the town which appears to have no independent character of its own, but takes its local colour from | from the various nationalities of which it is composed One of the serious defects in the life of this busy port is the prevailing custom of carrying on business on Sundays. It is urged, by way of excuse and explanation, that owing to the departure of the mailboats ou Monday, a pressure of wiirk falls upon the Sunday. Why this should necessarily be so is not quite clear, as, if Sunday were regarded as a 'dies non' for trading, the mail could easily be completed on the Saturday. "Where there's a will, there's a way' is never more conspicuously verified than in the observance of: Sunday The fact probably is that in this cosmopolitan town business would be severely handicapped were the respective days for religious observar ce very rigidly kept the Mosiems on Fridays, the Jews on Saturdays and the Christians on Sundays wa el turn cease to work, and it would seem talá compromise, wholly to the advantage of business, has been effected by observing all three days very indifferently, and, in the case of Sunday, scarcely at all. It is a deplorable state of things, seeing how many young Englishmen are engaged there who are deprived of that one day's rest in the week, which all Englishmen, apart from their proper objection to the secularizing of Sunday, are rightly agreed is so necessary to the maintenance of the 'mens sana in corpore sano.'

The signs of expansion and development, which are evident to those who have known Port Said in bygone years, encourage one to hope for still greater improvement in the near future, but much yet remains to make it an attractive resort. Hotel accomodation, it is true, is plenti. fal, and has greatly improved of late year There are few, if any, amusements calculated to attract them. A Jardin des Plantes or Zoological Gardens, and suited to the tastes of. persons of wealth and refinement, with promenades and verandahs which would tempt people to sit and listen to the strains of good music, and so forth, these attractions are yet to come. When they do come, the hurried few hours which visitors too often very grudgingly give to the place would gladly be extended to a more lengthened stay.

div.head: Savoy Hotel Dances.
div.p: The first small dance of the season at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be held on the 21st instant.

div.head: Cooper's Hill.
div.p: The annual Cooper's Hill dinner will be held at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, on the 27th instant.

div.head: The "Heliopolis."
div.p: The "Heliopolis" left Alexandria this afternoon at 2 p.m. for Marseilles direct, where she is due in three days time.

div.head: Supreme Consular Court.
div.p: The further hearing of the case, Carasso v. Carasso was adjourned this morning until Monday next, but will probably not be heard until Wednesday.

div.head: Pro Bono Publico.
div.p: A Society to be known as the Associazionë Internazionale di Pubblica Assistenza di Cairo has been formed by Dr. Abbate Pasha and Idris Bey Ragheb. The support of the public is earnestly solicited for this work of charity for the public good, and for this purpose a meeting will be to-morrow at 10a.m. in the Abbas Theatre.

div.head: Christmas Shopping in Egypt.
div.p: From Monday next there will be a grand exhibition at Walker and Meimaracbi's shop in the Rue de l'Ancienne Bourse of the latest novelties of all kinds of goods and stores, and especially of those articles suitable for Christmas presents in this and other countries. The shop will remain open all day on Sundays. Similar exhibitions will be displayed at Walker and Meimarachi's Ramleh branch at San Stefano, which will also remain open all day Sundays.

div.head: An Eel In a Pipe.
div.p: Some inconvenience has been caused in the Gizeh Zoological Gardens by the failure of the water supply to one part of the gardens. After a good deal of trouble (the snpply pipe having. to be dug up) the cause was found on the 10th December. An eel had somehow got into the pipe, and having travelled more than half a mile along it, decided to turn back. In turning theeelgot itself jamined and completely blocked the pipe, holding up the water (although under pressure) behind it. So tightly was the eel fixed in the pipe, that the workmen had to use some force to remove it. The eel when found was dead, but quite fresh. It was a large, fat specimen, 27 ½ inches in length.

div.head: Ribero's Circus.
div.p: Mr. Ribero's troupe of entertainers such as is usually found in a circas, made their debat last evening, and the large tent erected at the foot of the Rue de l'ancienne Bourse was literally packed in every part. The performance was on the whole a good one, and all the artistes were very well received. The programme contains several names new to Alexandria and there are also some old friends, among whoin is Mr. Ferony who gave us an excellent bare back turn. The juggling of Mr. Theodory received quite an oration, as did also "The Wily" who contributed some interesting feats of strength. The sisters Cardinali on the trapeze and Mlle. Ginevra on the slack wire also come in for a fair share of applanse Mr Ribero himself introduced several well traiued animals. The performance terminated with some excellent spring-board 'jumping by the Freres Zomfetta. "The clowning was rather better than usual,' but there is some room for improvement in the band.

div.head: Army of Occupation.
div.p: The Army and Navy Rifle Meeting, will be held on the Abbassia Rifle Ranges on Monday, 3rd ; Tuesday, 4th ; Wednesday, 5th; and Thursday, 6th, February, 1908, at which prizes to the value of about P.T. 50,400 will be given. The Individual Competitions will be as follows - Classification Matches for Marksman, 1st, 2nd and 3rd Class Shots and Recruits; All Service Comers ; Officers' Matches : Rapid Firing Competitions ; Inniskilling Fusiliers Competition ; Sir Eldon Gorst's, K.C.B, Championship: Egyptian Army Prize; Rifle and Revolver Pools ; Daily Sweepstakes ; which are open to all. There will also be 'Team Matches for prizes presented by:- The Sirdar: The G.O.C. in Egypt; "U" Bty., R.H.A.; The louiskilling Dragoons; The Coldstream Guards: The King's Own Scottish Borderers; The King's Royal Rifle Corps; The Inniskilling Fusiliers The Meeting will be conducted under A.R A roles. All entries to be in by January 3rd.

div.head: A PRESS DINNER
div.p: Last night a dinner was given by the members of the European Press in Cairo to their English, French and Belgian confrères, who are in Egypt to report on the Heliopolis Oasis The Chairman was M. Macrice Barrés of the French Academy, and Député de Paris. On either side of him were Mne Baudin and M Paul Adam. On the left of M. Pierre Baudin was Boghos Pasha Nubar.

Among the guests were Mr Parsons, M.Jules Huret of the "Figaro," M. Musel of the "Journal des Débats" : M. Gustave Tery of the "Matin": Mr. J. Sidney Low and Mr F. Marlowe of the "Daily Mail" ; M Casella, of "L'Auto" and "L'Intransigeant" ; M. Alberti of "Gil Blas", M. Galtier of the "Temps"; and the various members of the Cairo European Press.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
LETTER TO THE "STANDARD."
div.p: London, Saturday.

Abdul Razik writes to the "Standard" outlining the aims of the Party of the People. He urges the necessity of convincing the British public of the needs of higher education in Egypt, and the extension of organic law. The neglect of these is calculated to estrange Egyptians from the British, which estrangement mistaken enthusiasts might use as a fertile ground to sow seeds of dissension, which is hated alike by wise Egyptians and Englishmen.

div.head: WEATHER IN ENGLAND.
THAMES VALLEY FLOODED.
div.p: London, Saturday. The South of England has been deluged by rain and the Thames valley is flooded.

div.head:
PORTS AND LIGHTS.
THE TRIAL OF OFFICIALS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir ---A correspondent in the "Egyptian Gazette" to-day makes some serious imputations on the report which made of the trial of the officials of the Ports and Lights Administration before the Native Criminal Court at Alexandria. The correspondent hints that the version that was published was 'so untrue and incorrect as to make the trial appear as a "parody of justice." The object of the writer evidently is to use the hypothesis of the report being incorrect in order to criticise the sentences and this artful method of sheltering this criticism is not just to my report. If the writer had wanted to gauge the accuracy of the report, it was easy to compare it with the version given in "Al Moayad" or other native newspapers instead of assuming that the report is faulty, "the result of an imperfect knowledge of the Arabic language."
Truly Yours

div.head: THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
FRENCH COMPLAINTS.
div.p: As already reported by our special telegram of the 6th inst., in the debate on the French Budget of Foreign Affairs, M. Benazet asked the Minister for explanations concerning the resignation of M. Lembert, professor of jurisprudence at the Khedivial College of Cairo,and his place being taken by an Englishman. He laid great stress on what he termed the discourteous behaviour of Mr. Dunlop, the Under. Secretary for Instruction, which had brought about the withdrawal of the two French professors, MM. Grandmoulin and Lambert, and he did not spare the conduct of M. Lambert. In his opinion the resignation was a dereliction of duty, and, notwithstanding the wounds to his self esteem that M. Lambert might have had to suffer, he ought to have held to his post, and kept the Khedivial school in the possession of a Frenchman. Instead of doing this, he left without cven notifying the Government of his intention.

In reply to M. Benazet, M. Pichon said : "It is true that M. Lambert abandoned hig post without even informing our representative at Cairo. If he had done so, the French Minister would not have failed to bring forward the claims of France that justify her desire to see a Frenchman at the head of the Khedivial school. France has taken a most important part in the work of teaching in Egypt, especially in the teaching of law, and it is impossible that the British Government should not find sufficient grounds in their friendship for us to give due consideration to French interests in Egypt, especially in this matter of teaching. A discussion has been entered upon with Sir Edward Grey, and there is every reason to hope that it will result in our beris given satisfaction." It was inevitable that this question should have been brought up, and, considering the great amount of feeling that was aroused at the time, the above query and reply are remarkably moderate in their tone.

div.head: THE CAIRO SEASON
div.p: The Riviera's jealousy of Egypt is well known and no pains are spared to spread falsehoods in the English and French Press as to the awful dangers threatening the tourist here. The latest rumour is that cholera has broken out at Alexandria and the latest issue of the "St. James's Gazette and Evening Standard" contains the following :--

The exodus eastward has been much smaller this year than it was last, when Egypt enjoyed a season of exceptional prosperity. The many English people engaged in enterprises in the Khedive's (dominions have all felt the effect of a stringent money market, and naturally are not over anxious to welcome friends or relations. There is also a report of cholera on the North African Littoral, it being rumoured that cases have occurred even at Alexandria. The Riviera will naturally benefit. From Cannes to Bordighera a good: season is expected. Of course, nowadays the two most serious winter rivals to the Riviera and Egypt arě Biarritz and the high Alpine resorts. The latter are increasing in popularity ata tremendous pace, | and, what is more, are making staunch friends. Everybody who has been out there one winter returns and takes friends with him.

div.head: THE PERSIAN FRONTIER.
MILITARY ACTIVITY AT CONSTANTINOPLE.
div.p: London, Saturday,

Considerable activity is reported in military circles in Constantinople on the pretext of the concentration of troops in the vicinity of the Persian frontier. The Persian Government has informed the Porte that the allegations of military preparations are devoid of foundation.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: His Highness the Khedive arrived in Cairo on Thursday evening, with his son, the heir apparent, and his little daughter, both of whom we are glad to state now appear to be in excellent health. His Highness attended midday prayers yesterday at the Mosque el Malaroui, and returned to Koubbeh Palace for the rest of the day. The Khedive went to Cairo this morning to Abdin Palace and granted several private audiences

div.head: EGYPTIAN BALE MAKE UP.
A STANDARD FOR AMERICA.
div.p: The Chairman of the Oldham Cotton Buying Company (Mr. Thomas Coates), wbo repre. sented the company at the recent Atlanta International Cotton Conference, bas just issued a report of his visit to America. Of the committees appointed he was most interested in the one devoted to the handling and baling of cotton. It was agreed that the weight of the American bale should be 500 lbs. and, in other respects, as to bagging, bands and fastening, it should follow the make-up of the Egyptian cotton bale. Since the Convention, while travelling in the cotton belt, it was reported to Mr. Coates by a leading member of the Farmers' Union, that the railway companies will object to receive their freight bales packed in other bagging than that of jute. It was difficult to get reasons for this attitude, but it was thought that the four firms which control the jute packing industry in the cotton belt, who had large financial interests in railway companies, were working into the hands of the railways. It was reported by the Farmers' Union that they had always been told that spinners objected to any alteration.

div.head: EGYPT AS A REFUGE.
div.p: Egypt is a favorite resort for people who leave their country for their country's good. Some of the late members of the San Francisco Corporation are staying in Cairo judging from the following wire from San Francisco to a New York contemporary :

San Francisco, November 9—(Special to the Press) -A. K. Detweiler, the millionaire Toledan who was indicted here almost a year ago for having boodled through the Home Telephone Company's permit, is sojourning in Egypt, according to Detective Burns. Detweiler was the only one of the accused corporation men to run away and he has made good thus far chiefly because Burns has had too many other matters to look after. To make a citizen of the type of Detweiler a fugitive from justice in foreign lands may be as severe punishment as imprisonment. At least such is the detective's view. However, the millionaire by no means can feel assured that he will escape trial. One of those days he may find himself in the toils of the law, bound for San Francisco.

Jerry Driscon, brother-in-law of ex-Major Schmtiz, is enjoying the desert breezes of Cairo. Immediately after the graft prosecution began its investigations be disappeared. He had been associated with his brother-in-law in business and he was very much sought after by Burns for the testimony that it was thought he could give the grand jury. But when the subpoena was issued it was found that he had packed his belongings and departed. His disappearance saved him from a great deal of annoyance.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON AT MANCHESTER PORT.
div.p: Presiding at the annual meeting of the Manchester Cotton Association last week, Mr, F. Reyner, of Reyners, Ltd., said that statistics showed that last year they received at Manchester half the importations of Egyptian cotton to. Great Britain. Users of this growth did not require nearly the same pressure to take advantage of their port, and it did not need much of a prophet to foretell that within another ten years practically the whole of Egyptian Cotton used in Lancashire mills would come via the Manchester Ship Canal (applause).

The visitors to the Ship Canal the previous week saw the excellent conditions in which the Egyptian cotton was landed, and had ocular demonstration of the want of care in the pack. ing of the American bale ; for discharging their cotton side by side, were steamers from Alexandria, Egypt, and from Savannah, America. Turning to their Protective Committee's report, be found that the amount of damaged cotton landed in front of the American importations last season was 6.7 per cent, which compared with 5.5 and 9.2 per cent respectively in seasons 1905-6 and 1904-5—rather worse than last year, but better than two years ago. (Hear, hear.) In the case of Egyptian cotton there was a very marked difference. The percentage of the importations landed in a damaged condition only amounted to 1.05 per cent. -i.e., a decrease of about per cent on the season.

div.head: THE HELIOPOLIS OASIS.
A VISIT OF INSPECTION.
div.p: At the invitation of the Director-General of the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company, many of the distinguished visitors who arrived in Egypt by the "Heliopolis" this week, together with a large number of Cairo's well-known inhabitants, met at Shepheard's Hotel yesterday morning at a quarter to eleven, when special omnibuses were in waiting to convey them to the Heliopolis Oasis in order to view the works which are in progress there. The two motor omnibuses of the Oasis Company accomplished the journey in splendid time, and not the least enjoyable part of the day was this rush through a part of Cairo which is more or less unknown to the general Cairo people, for anless visiting Abbassia, it is seldom that the ordinary visitor travels in the direction in which the Oasis lies, hongh the road teems with an everchanging variety of scenery, and would be well worth traversing, even if the Heliopolis Oasis was not its goal.

From the time that the Waili district is reached the scene is an entirely different one to that met with in the town and by the time that the Oasis is reached it is hard to realize that Cairo with its city atmosphere of smoke and grime lies so very close to this spot which breathes of nature in its every aspect.

The first stop made was at the railway bridge in the Oasis itself, and from this point one gets a capital idea of the general position and appearance of this latest addition to the health and pleasure resorts of the world, for there is a fairly sharp rise up to the bridge, which might have been designed expressly for the purpose of shewing off the grandure and beauty of the surrounding country.

There will be three distinct services by rail and tramway to the Oasis, for there is the line from the Pont Limoun station in Cairo, which runs direct to the Heliopolis hotel, where the first stop is made and also a special rapid service of tramcars from and to Cairo, while the third is to be found in the local tramway service between the Oasis and Abbassia. The Grand Hotel which is now well on its way towards completion, is a magnificent building, and though it is as yet too early to write a detailed description of its accomodation, it is already evident that interior comfort will be added to the originality of its exterior design, and that it will equal in all respects the best hotels in the country.

The hall is large, and should be very pic. turesque when complete, with its dome of a height of 36 metres, and a very large room which will probably be set apart for the table d'hôte stands on the same floor, a broad and easy stair case leads up from either side of the hall to a large restaurant on the first floor, while higher still it is proposed to serve tea on what may easily be the finest roof garden in Egypt. It would be hard to imagine a more perfect view than that which is obtained from this point. Away to the west the domes and minarets of the Citadel stand clear and defined across a glowing ocean of sand, while further still the great pyramid rises into view, a silent guardian of the wide spaces of the world. Then on one hand the desert stretches away into eternal vastness, the brilliant dunes of sand changing and glowing with every atmospheric change, the shadow caused by a passing cloud melting away into a radiance of gold as the sun regains its vigour, and on the other hand lies a scene of almost equal charm where the lights of the desert mingle with the verdure of the cultivation in the vicinity of the town.

The hotel, with its gardens, will eventually occupy a space of about fifteen acres. In front of the hotel large shops and offices are already nearly complete, and a French company is busy in the erection of villas to the north which are being constructed to a variety of designs, and should ultimately give the place a very picturesque appearance.

Such a place as this promises to be, was hardly dreamed of a few years ago and there can be no doubt but what it will prove to be one of the most frequented resorts of Egypt ; the air is perfect, the views are as unique as they are wonderful, and all this lies within about a quarter of an hour of Opera Square.

At one o'clock an excellent luncheon was served in the one "Brasserie" which at present exists in the Oasis, and this place, by the, way, also bears the stamp of originality in its design, of which, the architect, M. Robida, has every reason to be proud.

At the conclusion of lunch Boghos Pasha Nubar made a short speech to the Assembled guests, and he was followed by M. Maurice Barres, and M. Paul Adam, while a short speech by Maitre Carton de Wiart terminated the proceedings.
The guests were photographed on the steps of the building, before, with many expressions of satisfaction at what they had been shewn, they entered the omnibuses for the return journey to Cairo.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wlah, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limites--free discussion

div.head:
THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
WANTED A MAP.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, I saw in the "Egyptian Gazette" that the Survey Department intends having an exhibition of maps shortly and it is therefore very opportune if you will allow me to air a problem, which I have never yet had satisfactorily explained. That is, why does not the Survey Department publish a map of Egypt with all the latest discoveries and observations ? The Delta and the strip of cultivation np to the frontier, including the Oasis of the Fayoum, are mapped, but beyond the 12,000 square miles of settled and cultivated country all the rest, so far as maps available to the general public are concerned, is an atter blank. Yet these 12,000 square miles are less than one thirtieth part of Egypt, which has a total area of about 400,000 square miles. It is a pity that the Survey Department does not publish a general map of the country with all the results of its work delineated. It would of course be very incomplete, for the topography of the Libyan desert will never be satisfactorily known until the navigation of airships is per. fected. But an enormous amount of excellent work has of late been done by the Survey Department and it is quite impossible to get an idea of the results from any map of Egypt and Sinai. In one good-looking map published lately, which lies before me, the Libyan Desert is plastered with the superscription "AngloEgyptian Condominium," wherein the Oasis of Khufra is included! The western frontier of Egypt is understood to run from the Gulf of Sollown southwards, including the five Oases of Siwa, Baharia, Parafra, Dakkla and Kharga, and although the western boundary of Egypt beyond these Oasis is as yet unsettled, there is no reason why there should not be some general map published. There is no map, for example of the Mariout district.

The Coastguard Administration has a general chart of the desert, but it has never been accurately controlled. In fact these observations of the desert appear to have been completely ignored by cartographers for the great salt lake or marsh south of the desert plateau by Mersa Matrouh is never marked on any of the latest maps of Africa and yet it is the most prominent feature in the chart of the Coastguard Administration. None of the latest maps of Egypt contain any reference to the recently discover. ed Oasis of Iddaila, to the West of Paratra, although it is mentioned in the report on the Farafra Oasis, published by the Survey Department as long ago as 1901. The records of scientific travellers of the road from Babaria to the Siwa Oasis are never noticed in any of the latest maps, although the records of Belzoni, Pacho And' Ascherson could easily be controlled by the Survey Department. I am unaware of any general map of Egypt containing the latest observations on the de. sert between Farafra and Dakhla sinoe Rohlf's Expedition more than thirty years ago. Yet all these tracks have been traversed by scientific persons of late years and it is extraordin. ary that their observations have not been perpetuated by cartographers. It is still more extraordinary that the Survey Department does not make an attempt at a general map of the country. Years ago, in 1894, the present head of that Department wrote a most interesting report on a patrol to the Western Oases and since then reports dealing with that portion of Egypt have been published by Messrs. Beadnell and Ball. But up to now. all their observations are concealed in official reports and never see the light of dny in a general map. The same criticism could be made on the case of the Eastern Desert and the Sinaitic Peninsula. Meanwhile we have to be content with Justus Perthes' maps of Egypt and North Africa. That. excellent German publisher, who issues the most informing annual in the world, the Almanach de Gotha, is of course beyond reproach as a cartographic publisher, but whenever I see his maps of Egypt I always note & considerable number of omissions, which could ba easily supplied by Survey officials in Egypt, and yet their observations are allowed to lie unnoticed in the unilluminablo catacombs of the official reports. Surely even with the prevailing mania for economy the Egyptian Government might see its way to granting a small credit for the publication of an annual map of Egypt giving all the latest results of the work done by the Survey Department so far as concerns its ģeographical and cartographical bearings.
I am, Sir,
Truly Yours

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince and Princess A. Lieven are staying at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan.
The Duchess de Montecalvo Pignaletti has arrived in Egypt and will spend the season at Cairo.
Countess della Cisterna is also a visitor to the Cataract Hotel.
Coles Pasha is making a tour in Upper Egypt. He is at present at the Cataract Hotel Assouan.
Sir Malcolm Mellwraith is touring Upper Egypt on inspection.
Among those staying the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, are Count Lavison, Count Zizinin, Sir and Lady Bedford, Sir W. Sitwell, Baron Teuffell von Berkensee, Maher Pasha, Birch Basha, and Padoa Bey.

div.head:
FAR EAST PROBLEM.
ACTIVITY OF FRENCH FLEET.

div.p: Orders have been received to report upon the condition of warships and crews available for service in the Pacific to reinforce the relief drafts for Indo-China. It is understood that is in view of the unrest in the Far East. (Reuter.)
France and England have concluded an agreement repressing fiscal frauds. Steps will assure the perception of succession dues and income tax. (Havas.)

Great Britain and France have signed a convention providing for exchange of information regarding the death duties and estates of Frenchmen domiciled in Great Britain, and vice versa. It is stated that this is preliminary to a series of measures by which M. Caillaux will obtain information regarding the estates of Frenchmen abroad in connection with the Income Tax. (Reuter)
Cricket. First test match. At lunch time England's score was 106 runs for 3 wickets. (Reuter)
Test Match. England 273; Gunn made 119 runs. Australia's score is 50 runs for 1 wicket, (Reuter)
Troops occupy all the strategic points in Zululand. Columns are searching the country for prominent rebels. The end of the operations is near. (Reuter)
The heavy rains have culminated in foods in the Midland and Southern counties. Thousands of acres of land are under water. Much damage has been done. (Reuter)
The Lower House has passed the "Ausgleich" by a large majority. (Reuter)
The Kaiser had visited the Queen. Cordial - toasts were exchanged at the banquet recalling their common origin. The Emperor left at 9 40 (Havas)
The German Emperor has arrived. He was cheered by crowds. He was received by Queen Wilhelmina and Prince Henry. (Reuter)
The Senatorial Commission, rejecting the 28 days military service, M. de Freycinet has resigned the presidency. (Havas)
There is a complete strike of gas employés. (Havas)
The Reichstag has adjourned until January. (Havas)
The Duke and Duchess of Fife and their daughters have left for Gibraltar for the benefit of the Duchess's health. (Reuter)

The Hamburg firm of Woenckhaus has appealed to the Foreign Office against the seizure of their warehouse alleged to contain contraband on Abu Musa island in the Persian Gulf, by H.M.S. Lapwing. The Hamburg newspapers are indignant : (Reuter)
Owing to its rejection the Government has abandoned the general ex-propriation clause of the Polish Bill. It also restricts it to certain areas and reduces the grant to £13,000,000. (Reuter)

There is considerable activity in military circles on the pretext of the concentration of Persian troops on the frontier. Orders have been given to reinforce the troops at contested points. Ammunition and rifles have been despatched thither. Perter Pasha is proceeding to Bagdad. (Reuter)
The King has ordered that the Italian language alone should be used on court menus and that only Italian wines should be served. (Reuter)
Prince George and his bride will spend their honeymoon at Taormina. (Reuter)
Lieutenant Woods has received a request from the War Office to resign his commission otherwise he would be removed from the army, under clause No. 477. (Reuter)
Obituary. George McCulloch, the silver magnate. (Reuter)

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
DECEMBER RACE MEETING.
div.p: Cairo, Friday, The entries for this meeting were very satisfactory, the racing was excellent, and we have seldom seen so many close finishes on the same day, the excitement being sustained up to the very end in practically each event. The weather was again kind to us and the attendance large ; Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst, Mr. Machell, and most of the notables of Cairo were present. There were not so many visitors as last year, but in these hard times we do not expect quite the same number. The handicapping worked out well, and the handicappers may be congratulated on the close finishes. Capt. Leigh, Mr. Branch, and Mr. Michaelides, very kindly in the absence of Mr. Reid, helped with the starting, and, moreover, helped successfully seeming to get their horses away well together. The brakes supplied by the club for the use of members were not patronised, but the repartee exchanged between the cabbies and the brake drivers was no doubt entertaining to those lucky enough to understand.

The first race saw Chameleon again to the fore ; his late owner might be seen with a gloomy look thinking deeply of the chances he had lost and the small sum he had taken in exchange for the probable Jubilee winner Chameleon ran a grand race to day, and so far we have not seen him ridden out at the finish. Bahlul's performance in the second race was decidedly good ; not yet 4 years old, he is undoubtedly a good horse, and should do well in the future. Mulberry had to be content with second place. In the third race Capt. H. B Kennedy did well ; being rather shut in at the start he found a way through and came with a rush at the finish. By the way I may offer a little advice to jockies in two furlong races, that is ride the first furlong as hard as you jolly well can, and the second a jolly site

harder, and if you don't win it is not your fault," We congratulate Mr. Evans the sporting owner of Fares on his win in the Hurdle Race he should be, and is, very grateful to Kamel Effendi for the splendid race he rode Grey Dawn has now put the third win to his credit, and ran a very good horse. Stillwell showed great judgment, making his effort just at the right time. For the sixth race Sattam, who has no luck this year, looked like winning but "cut it" at the finish Capt. Leigh on Nigmah riding a good race snatched the verdict.
(FROM OUR LADY CORRESPONDENT).

To-day's meeting was the largest we have had this season, and there was quite a good show of pretty froeka, though the wind was keen enough to necessitate most ladies donning fura and big cloaks of divers descriptions. Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst arrived quite early in the afternoon : and among the others present were noticed :-Count Von Bernstoff with Miss von Bernstoff, Mr. Machell and Lady Valda Machell, the Hon : Mr. and Mrs. Iddings, the Hon : 0. James and Mrs. James, General and Miss Bullock with whom was · Miss Otway, Watson Pasha and Mrs. Watson, Major and Mrs. Robertson Eustace, Major Haig, Captain and Mrs. Duffus, Captain and Mrs. Bailey, Captain and Mrs Fitzgerald, Captain Stirling, Captain and Mrs. Sobreiber, Captain Trefusis, Captain and Mrs. Darrell, Captain and Mrs. Clifford Hall, Mr. and Mrs. Balkeley Johnson, who came with a party, Mr. Chas Royle also with friends, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Dalgleish, Mr. and Mrs. Appleton, Mr. and Mrs. Williamson, Mrs. and Miss Alan Joseph, Mrs. and Miss Rees, Mrs. Kershaw.

It is an invidious matter to make comparisons where dress is concerned, and certainly there were so many charming toilettes to be noticed that it is not possible to say which was worn with greatest effect. Lady Gorst was in pale blue with a heavily braided cape-coatee with long tails, and she wore an enormous black cloche hat with beautiful feathers.

Mrs. James was wearing a frock of palest grey with a hat of rough felt in dull purple. Lauly Rogers was very smart in black and white with touches of gold ball fringe upon the bodice. Fringe also bordered the quaint loose cape of green worn by Mrs. Bailey over a dress of black and white striped chiffon, the skirt being bordered also with green. Mrs. Scott Dalgleish was in pale blue, ber hat being particularly fresh and becoming. Miss Rees was wearing a very well fitting coat and skirt of brown with green facings ; and her big cloche hat with its streaming plumage was particularly admired. There were one or two very striking toilettes in black ; and some exceedingly pretty ones in soft shades of buff, brown and white stripes, and a quite lovely one of a painted chiffon in soft shades of brown that were welcome to the eye.

Anyway it is satisfactory to note after the display, that whatever our belles of Cairo have to deny themselves this winter they have no intention of curtailing their wardrobes, or losing their reputation for taste sartorial.

div.head: Coton
div.p: La semaine qui vient de finir a été, à plus d'un point de vue, très intéressante et, cette fois, c'est anx nouvelles d'Amérique que l'attrait doit être attribué en grande partie. Cela s'explique d'ailleurs facilement, car il ne nous est pas toujours donné d'avoir à 24 heures d'in-. tervalle deux faits capitaux aussi importants que les Rapports du Censuş Burean et du Bureau d'Agriculture, surtout que de prime abord ces deux publications ont commencé par produire l'effet contraire à celui qui aurait dû être la conséquenee des chiffres énoncés par elles. Mais n'anticipons pas et, suivant notre formule habitnelle, procédons par ordre. Samedi, la tenue de notre marché a été très ferme et c'est en hausse de 3/32 sur la veille que la séance a fini. Cette même allure du reste a aussi caractérisé la journée de Landi qui a encore clôturéplus fermeque lejour précédent.

Jusques-là il n'y avait rien de bien extraor dinaire, le fait étant que cette fermeté était causée par les pronosticsd un rapport do Census Bureau indiquant une petite récolte, mais ce qui a un peu étonné tout le monde ça a été de voir qu'au lieu d'une hausse plus ou moins forte, c'est la baisse qui nous a été annoncée le lendemain et cela malgré la différence en moins de 1,700,000 Balles dans la quantité égrenée au 30 Novembre !

Toutefois, cette circonstance n'a pas en * beaucoup d'effet sur notre marché qui est resté relativement soutenu, dans l'attente de l'estimation du Bureau d'Agriculture devant arriver le soir et qui effectivement nous est venue avec le chiffre de 11,678.000 balles, contre 12,546,000 l'année dernière

Ce rapport, reçu aprés les heures de travail, semblait devoir nous apporter des nouvelles inflammatoires pour nos haussiers, mais, contre toate attente, c'est avec 45 à 50 points de baisse que New-York a fermé. Le fait n'étant pas naturel, notre spéculation a pensé avec raison qu'il devait y avoir anguille sous roche; aussi, après un début faible et en baisse d'environ 1/4 de tallari, des tentatives de soutien furent-elles faites, en attendant de voir quelles suites ce rapport pourrait bien avoir. Comme premier gi.ccès, nos cours n'ont pas tardé à regagner presque tout le champ perdu à la première beure ; mais ce qui a été plus satisfaisant pour nos haussiers, c'est la reprise mar. quée que les dépêches d'Amérique nous ont servie le soir même. Ce prompt revirement' seinble être du au fait que sur la première impression du rapport des liquidations de positions haussières très importantes avaient eu lieu, mais qu'une fois le coup fait, les haussiers mêmes avaient tourné casaque.

En tous cas, la journée d'hier a été d'une grande fermeté et ce matin les choses ont eu l'air, sur la continuation de la hausse en Amérique, de vouloir s'accentuer ou tout an moins de persister dans cette voie; mais, à la suite du désir de réaliser montré par un des leaders de la hausse, il y a en lutte entre copains et la journée a fini d'une façon inattendue sur la cote de 1911/32 pour le janvier et 20 5/16 pour le mars.

C'est en somme, un recul de 1/4 et de 5/32 sur la cote de vendredi dernier, mais ce qui est plus sérieux dans tout ceci, c'est la preuve que cet incident nous fonrnit sur le peu d'élasticité de notre marché et la perspective qu'il nous met en vue pour le jour où, après avoir fait la hausse par leurs achats et à leurs propres de. pens, nos détentcurs de contrats voudront, se débarrasser de leurs positions.

On pourra continuer à nous traiter de pessi'mistes, mais on ne nous contestera plus anjour. d'hui que pour le moins nos opinions sont basées et que pour consolider éventuellement les cours factices du moment, il faut autre chose que l'action combinée des quatre ou cinq faiseurs qui mènent actuellement le train.

Ce quelque chose a paru leur sourire ces derniers temps quand la filature anglaise, chauffée à blanc sur la question de la rareté du Mit Affifi, s'est présentée aux achats, mais comme cette demande ne s'est pas développée et que dans tous les cas, le continent n'a pas suivi, nous nous trouvons, pour ainsi dire, dé nouveau à notre point de départ. On dit que l'Amérique aussi a bougé un peu pour nos cotons ; c'est possible, mais il ne faut pas se faire trop d'illusions sur ce point, le doute n'étant plus permis sur la réduction très sensible dans la consommation de l'Egyptien à laquelle il faut s'attendre pour cette campagne qux Etats-Unis.

En résumé, notre marché est restreint et pour peu que le commerce continue ses ventes en contrats, nous ne voyons pas coinment le maintien des prix pourrait se faire. Pour aujourd'hui, comme premier résultat de ces ventes, nous voyons le report de Janvier à Mars s'élargir à 1 tallari, mais après ! A nos sagaces lecteurs de conclure.

Le Novembre 1908 a commencé à intéresser le Commerce et l'on affirme que ce dernier a fait quelques affaires en cette échéance, comme vendeur bien entendu. Nous ne sommes pas en mesure de contrôler l'information, mais ce qui est incontestable, c'est que la prochaine récolte trouve depuis quelques jours, relative ment parlant, un marché plus large.

Et pour finir avec notre marché aux contrats, ajoutons maintenant que pour ce qui concerne l'activité, il n'y a pas lieu de se plaindre ; d'ailleurs, l'Amérique n'a pas été avare envers nous avec les prétextes de nature å stimuler les affaires.

Pour revenir à l'Amérique, non devons constater que les opinions au sujet du Bureau sont très partagées : les uns le disert tout près de la réalité et le considèrent très haussier tandis que les autres, se rappelant les estima tions des trois années précédentes affirinent le contraire, leur avis etant que la filature ne saurait jamais absorber 12 1/2 à 12 3/4 millions de baller, surtout après la crise financière amé ricaine et ses belles conséquences et le fait queeg ressources invisibles se sont trouvées être de eaucoup supérieures à ce que l'on disait. Il st vrai que l'on prétend que la crise est sur e point de finir et qu'il y a réveil dans la lemande pour les manufactures et les filés. Sor e premier point on peut dire que ce ne sont as les nouvelles suspensions et les continuels uicides des directeurs de banques en Amérique qui nous le prouveraient, tandis que la areté du numéraire dans l'Intérieur ne cesse l'être une sentrave à la reprise des affaires égulières par la filature américaine. Quant au éveil de la demande, il est particulier à l'An. leterre et même seulement partiel pour les ndes; par contre, les avis du Continent sont moirs, surtout de l'Allemagne, où il y a déjà eurois faillites importantes, à ce que l'on dit, Hans le monde industriel et où l'on craint l'explosion d'une forte crise. En attendant, l'escompte renchérit de nonveau.

A notre avis, tous ces conseils d'achats qui nous viennent de New-York sont enachés de partialité : il y a une manipotation spéculative en cours et l'on cherhe simplement des appuis au dehors, et i l'on voulait un indice prouvant le bien Fondé de cette manière de penser on n'a qu'à entendre Price qui dit s'attendre à unrochain Census Bureau très haussier, après que lui-même en date du 4 Décembre a soutenu que ces rapports étaient de nulle valeur et que généralement ils sont de 40 % au-dessous de la réalité ! N'oublions pas non plus que la quescion de l'égrenage ne signifie plus rien maintenant que nous avons eu l'estimation de la récolte par le Bureau d'Agriculture.
Notre marché du disponible a été assez acif dans son ensemble, avec une bonne demande pour les qualités fines, tandis que les cotons courants ont été constamment offerts.

Quant à la cote officielle, elle nous montre ape hausse de 1,4 pour les Good Affifi et 1/8 pour les Fully good fair et les Good fair, tandis que les Fully fair et les Fair sont sans changement. Les Haute Egypte de leur côté ont aussi gagné 1/8 pour les Good fair et au dessus. Dans es variétés, l'Abassi reste inchangé, mais le Joannovich avance de 1/4 pour le Good et Extra et le Nubari de 1/2 tallari. pour les nêines classements.
Les exportations ont été même inférieures aux prévisions, leur total n'ayant atteint que 33,000 Balles, contre 43,000 l'année dernière.
Pour la semaine prochaine on prévoit une nouvelle réduction sur les 36,000 Balles de la nême période en 1906.

Dans notre précédente revue, nous avons hentionné que les exportations de Décembre 1906 s'étaient élevées à 156,000 Balles. Ajourons maintenant comme simple constatation que les embarquements effectifs du 1er au 12 Décembre inclusivement sont de Balles 52396, contre 63774 pour 1906 ; que les expéditions pour I Amérique pour cette même période sont He Balles 4880, contre Balles 10334 ; que les recettes à ce jour sont de 62000 cantars supérieures à celles de l'année dernière ; que le déficit dans les exportations est de 27000 Cantars ; que le stock est de 41000 Cantars de plus; que l'augmentation dans les re. traits de l'Angleterre tombe à 9500 Balles, tandis que la différence en moins dans ceux du Continent est de 8500 Balles et dana ceux de l'Amérique de 6500 Balles. Nous revienHrons probablement sur ces points plus d'une fois à l'avenir.

Liverpool a été peu actif pour les Egyptiens, Enais, comme prix, la tenue a été assez bonne après tont. Le spot est à 10 3/16 et les futurs Janvier à 9 62/64, soit respectivement 1/16 ct 1/64 de bausse pour la semaine.

Les américains, par contre, ont donné lieu à des affaires très roniles et pour ce qui est de Ha cote, elle est à 6.38 pour le spot, soit 3 points de hausse depuis vendredi. Les futurs en clo ture sont renseignés à 5.93 pour le JanvierFévrier et 5.95 pour le Mars-Avril, ce qui nous fait 7 et 5 points de hausse.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Les arrivages ont été copieux et en rapport avec la saison, mais par suite du ralentissement de la demande pour l'exportation, les cours du disponible ont da fléchir un pen et finissent aujourd'hui à P.T 68.
En contrats, très peu d'affaires, mais la cote se maintient quand même assez bien. Derniers prix affichés P.T. 1 pour le Décembre Janvier et P.T. 74 1 2 pour le Février Mars.

L'Angleterre est très calme pour les rappro: chés, les cours du flottant étant de £ 6.8/9 et ceux du Décembre £ 6.11/3, avec peu d'affaires. Le Février Mars, par contre, vaut £6.16/3. II y a des réventes des fabricants'en disponible et en flottant.
les huiles prêtes sont faibles; les éloignées, par contre, assez fermes. Les tourteaux sont toujours dans la même situation.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: LA SEMAINE Il n'est pas possible cette semaine de passer en revue les séances de notre marché des valeurs. Elles sont toutes analogues. Aucun titre n'a particulièrement attiré l'attention. Les agents de change, qui se plaignent amèrement du manque d'ordres, désertent en grande partie la corbeille et les quelques rernisiers obligés d'être présents pour la forme restent assis sur la rampe. Cette désespérante inactivité est la conséquence naturelle de la situation gén rale ; le déclin de la crise monétaire pousse les vegdeurs empresgés de nagnère à I limiter lleurs ordres de liquidations à des prix que les acheteurs peu confiants encore dans une amélioration définitive ne sont nullement disposés à payer. Les uns et les autres font preuve de bon sens. Il est évident, en effet, que les détenteurs de bonnes valeurs égyptien nes auraient tort de s'en défaire aux bas cours actuels, hormis le cas de nécessité, et d'autre part rien ne permet de prévoir dans un avenir immédiat une détente inonétaire assez tappréciable pour engager les capitaux disponibles à absorver le flottant. Une reprise est d'autant plus improbable pour le moment que nous entrons dans la période des inventaires qui correspond généralement à un fléchissement de la cote. Si les transactions ont fait défaut, on a du moins la satisfaction de constater que les cours se sont maintenus dans l'ensemble. Etant donné que dans les circonstances actuelles il suffit de quelques titres offerts ou demandés pour faire osciller la cote dans un seng ou dans l'autre, les fluctuations n'offrent, bien entendu qu'un intérêt médioore et n'ont qu'une im portance toute relative, en l'absence d'échanges fermes pour les sanctionner.

FLUCTUATIONS DE LA COTE Sur une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle de notre bourse, 25 sont en baisse et 12 seulement en hausse, les autres demeurent stationnaires aux cours antérieurs.

Parmi les variations les plus importantes, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire perdent 8 francs, la Daïra Sanieh 1/4 et les Markets 2 shellings et 9 pence, tandis que la Société de Pressage gagne 1 livre et les Nungovich Hotels 1/4.

La National Bank recule de 3/ 6, l'Urbaine de 1/8, la Delta Light, la Delta Land, la fondateur Comptoir et l'Helouan de 1/16, l'Agricole, l'Investment, les Estates, les Cotton Ginners, la Levant, les Ritz et la Levico de 1/32, le Comptoir et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 3/32, les Dividendes Bière d'Alexandrie de 1 fr., la Cassa di Sconto de 0 fr 25, la Banque d'O. rient de 1 fr. 25, la Salt and Soda et l'Aboukir de 6 pence, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 1 shelling et la Port Said Salt de 3 pence.

La Ramleh, après avoir avancé de 4 5/16 à 4 1/2 est revenue en clôture a 4 3/8. Les Tramways d'Alexandrie bénéficient de 1 fr. les Privilegiées et de 2 fr. les Dividendes, l'Alex. andria Water de 1/8, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Poncier et les Lots Turcs de 1 fr., la Banque d'Athènes de 0 fr. 50, les Sucreries de 2 francs, le Banco di Roma de 1 fr. 50 et l'Action Allotment de 1/16.
SUR LES MARCHES BUROPEENS

En Europe la situation parait un peu moins bonne que vendredi dernier. Sans parler du taux privé d'escompte qui remonte de 5 7/8 à 6% et du Consolidé qui perd 1/4 de livre à 83, les valeurs égyptiennes subissent une dépré. ciation assez sensible, du moins la Daïra et la National Bank qui s'inscrivent en baisse respective de 1/2 et de 1/4. A Paris, la Rente gagne 48 points, mais l'Unifiée Egyptienne perd 1 fr. et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien 1 fr. 50. Sur le reste il n'y a pas de changements à signaler. La réserve de la Banque d'Angleterre progresse de 44 à 47%, grâce sans doute à son taux d'escompte supérieurde 1 % au taux privé.
LA CRISE EGYPTIENNE
Ici, les faillites se produisent en quantités. Les tribunaux regorgent de protêts et d'assignations. Au rôle de lundi du tribunal mixte de commerce figuraient 150 procès.

On est heureux de signaler au milieu de ces désastres l'arrangement intervenu ces jours-ci dans l'une des faillites les plus sensationnelles de cette année. Mardi, en effet, a eu lieu la réunion des créanciers de la maison Khalifa Naggar et fils. Elle a abouti au vote du concordat préventif. On dit que MM. Khalifa Naggar et fils se sont engagés à payer intégraJement leurs créanciers en l'espace de trois ans avec intérêts à raison de 3 % l'an. La réunion au tribunal mixte pour l'homologation du concordat aura lieu le 18 décembre.
Societes NOUVELLES

Les innombrables sociétés nouvelles, qui ont été créées ici pendant ces dernières années et dont les cours ont passé par des fluctuations fantastiques pour finir aux prix dérisoires actuels, sont l'objet depuis quelque temps de l'attention générale. Personne n'ignore que leurs financiers promoteurs ont largement contribué par leurs maneuvres spéculatives à précipiter le marché égyptien dans l'impasse où il se trouve actuellement, et cela bien avant que la crise américaine se soit déclarée. Ce qui a perinis aux administrateurs de ces sociétés de diriger aussi légèrement les intérêts de leurs actionnaires, c'est la constitution même des compagnies sous la législation anglaise avec un conseil d'administration étranger, ce qui délivre celui ci de toute juridiction pénale en cas de mauvaise gestion. Ce vice de constitution, qui nous a valu de nombreux abus, ruineux pour l'épargne locale, aurait été l'objet d'un sérieux examen en hant lieu. Cependant, il n'est pas yrai que le Foreign Office ait invité Sir Eldon Gorst à étudier la situation des sociétés financières d'Egypte constituées sous la législation anglaise. Du moins l'Agence Britannique ne sait absolument rien de ces prétendues démar. ches du Foreign Office. Selon toate apparence, on laissera au temps le soin d'arranger les choses et d'inculquer à l'épargne locale un peu plus de clairvoyance pour l'avenir.

Un intérêt de palpitante actualité en ce temps de pénurie monétaire se rattache aux appels de fonds formulés par ces petites so ciétés. L'actionnaire, avant d'opérer de nouveaux versements, exige qu'on lui rende compte de ce qu'on a fait des premiers et il n'a pas tort. Il est d'autant plus antorisé à agir de la sorte que plusieurs des nouvelles entreprises sont notoirement dans des situa tions équivoques et que les autres s'obstinent à ne fournir aucun renseignement sur l'état de leurs affaires. D'autre part, pourquoi irait-on verser à un Conseil d'Administration qui refuse des comptes an solde de 10 ou 15 shelling par titre qu'on peut acquérir sur place à ? shellings ou même moins ? Tel est le problème qui se pose pour les sociétés nouvelles, don un certain nombre ont été lancées par de financiers peu scrupuleux, qui ont ainsi rénsa à passer au publio bénévole des entreprise qui périclitaient ou des terrains sans acquéreurs.

div.head: I took Per-un-a, Hardly Daring to Believe
div.p: Pelvic Diseases in Men.

"I am an old war veteran. I contract." ed severe bladder and kidney trouble. I spent hundreds of dollars and consulted a host of doctors, but neither did me any good.

"Finally some of my comrades who had been cured by Pernna advised me to try it. I at once bought a bottle, and found it helped me so much that I kept using it for nearly four months. Peruna has proven the best medl. cine I ever used. My pals are gone and I believe myself to be cured. I feel well, and would not be without a bottle In time of need for ten times its cost."
Mr. Robert E. Hanvoy, Treasurer Knights of Industrial Freedom, also a well known writer and lecturer, writes
from 11 South Nicholas Rt., Chicago, III., as follows:

"I was in good health until about four years ago, when my back became lamo and sore. The pains kept increasing, with severe twitches and slow exhaustive aches. Urine was highly colored and passed with great irregularity. I knew this must be Inflammation of the bladder.

"Having read of Peruna I decided to try it, I found relief from the main Within ten days. The aches gradually diminished, and it was a blessed relief I can assure you. When three months I was well once more, My appetite had returned, nervousness and irritability were things of the past, and for over two years now I have been a healthy man.
"I give all thanks to your Peruna. and believe that it is a blessing to mankind."
Catarrh of the Bladder.
Mr.C. B. New hof, 10 Delaware street, Albany, N. Y., President Montefiore Clubs, writes:

"Since my advanced age I find that l have been frequently troubled with urinary ailments. The bladder seemed Irritated, and my physician said that it was catarrh caused by a protracted cold which would be difficult to overcome on account of my advanced age. I took Peruna, hardly daring to believe that I would be helped, but found to my relief that I soon began to mend. The irritation gradually subsided, and the urinary difficulties passed away, I have enjoyed excellent Health now for the past seven months, I enjoy my meals, sleep soundly,and am as well as I was twenty years ago. For special directions everyone should read "THE ILLS OF LIFE", a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.
The following wholesale druggist will supply the retail trade in Cairo and Alexandria, Egypt.
E. DEL MAR.
LES CAPITAUX BELGES EN Egypte

On sait que la Belgique a partieipé, par l'apport de ses capitaux, d'une façon prépondéranto à la mise en valeur du sol égyptien ; au cours de ces dernières années, de nombreuses sooiétés belges et belgo-égyptiennes ont vu le jour et la plupart sont dans une situation florissante témoignant de la perspicacité et du bons pratique de ceux qui en jetè. rent les bases. Les intérêts belges en Egypte sont évalués à 400 millions de francs. Outre quatre sociétés agricoles de la plus sérieuse importance, les Belges ont grandement contribué à créer deux sociétés financières, 'cing sociétés immobilières, deux sociétés à la fois agricoles et immobilières, deux sociétés de construction, la grande entreprise d'Héliopolis, quatre sociétés indastrielles et trois sociétés commerciales ; mais où l'autorité belge triomphe definitivement, c'est dans l'exploitation des moyens de transports. Au total, trente-deux organisations, toutes sérieuses et prospères, affirmant au pays Khédivial l'esprit d'entreprise des Belges.

Au nombre de ces sociétés il faut placer l'Anglo-Belgian Co. of Egypt qui a tenu sa seconde assemblée ordinaire le 28 écoulé. Il résulte do rapport lu par le président da Conseil d'Administration que les résultats ont été satisfaisants eu égard à la crise. On sait que l'Anglo-Belgian a été constituée au capital de £ 1.000.000 en 200.000 actions de £ 5. Il a été placé jusqu'ici 70,000 actions, ce qui donne un capital disponible de £ 346,030. La société a acquis les quatre cinquièmes de la Fayoum Light Railways Company dont le réseau d'exploitation est de 168 kilomètres dans la riche province du Fayoum. L'Anglo-Belgian a également acheté à Choubrah 10,612 m2 de terrains, qui ont été divisés pour la revente en 22 lots. Un de ces lots a déjà été vendu avec un bénéfice tel que si les autres sont cédés avec un profit moitié moindre, la transaction globale donnera un bénéfice de 12 à 15,0. O livres. Le compte profits et pertes de l'exercice se solde par un bénéfice net de £ 2.311.
LA SITUATION EN AMERIQUE.

D'Amérique les nouvelles continuent à être peu favorables. 11,000 étrangers sont partis samedi de New-York pour l'Europe. La Kansas City National Bank of Commerce, qui a sug. I pendu ses paiements, a un passif de 24.000.000 dollars. A la suite de ce dépôt de bilan M. Cortelyou a demandé à toutes les banques nationales de lui communiquer un exposé de leur situation. D'autre part, la Fortpitt National Bank of Pittsburg a été formée par ordre du Contrôle. Son passif atteint 5,500.000 dollars. Comme si tont cela ne suffisait pas, "Eeho de Paris" a pablié qu'une grande acti vité régnait à l'arsenal de Toulon en raison de graves nouvelles reçues de la tension américojaponaise. Bien qu'elle ne sorte pas du domaine de la possibilité, cette dernière rumeur parai invraisemblable en présence des déclarations ultra-pacifiques de M. Taft à St. Pétersbourg.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
